conclusion: Understand the problem of light incident on a transparent medium sphere and determine if it will be totally internally reflected.
Light enters the sphere at point A and refracts according to Snell's Law, then approaches the boundary at point B.
Snell's Law: n1 sin(i) = n2 sin(r), where n1 is the refractive index of air, n2 is the refractive index of the sphere.
Total internal reflection occurs when light travels from a medium with a higher refractive index to a lower one, with an incidence angle greater than the critical angle.
The critical angle θc can be calculated using: sin(θc) = n2/n1.
Light reaches the boundary at point B and attempts to exit the sphere with an incidence angle i'.
Compare i' and θc: if i' > θc, total internal reflection occurs; if i' ≤ θc, light refracts out.
If incident angle i at point A is large enough, i' at point B may exceed θc, resulting in total internal reflection.
Final conclusion: If i is sufficiently large, light will be totally internally reflected at point B.
